5139: Dominating Licid.author: XTwistedsoulX
5139: Dominating Licid.text_parsed:
These were difficult to get rid of, aside from nailing it before the summoning sickness was done.
Heres a few ways to deal with them now if you got a friend who uses (Abuses) these old school gems.

#1 : Krosan Grip,Sudden Death, Sudden Shock Or anything simular. Split Second will not allow time for any switcharoo antics.
#2 : Planar Cleansing or any other mass removal that hits both cretures and enchantments at the same time.
#3 : Abeyance, Cursed Totem, City of solitude or any other card that can throw off activated abilitys. Some, like Bind simply require common sense timing.
#4 : You can always upend the table, yell like a barbarian and refuse to play. Its not proper ettiquite but good lord is it effective. :)

@blindthrall: That won't work. Once the wrath resolves, state based actions put the Licid into the graveyard for not enchanting anything before you can get priority, and ending the effect is a special action that you can only take when you have priority.

@muffinmafia: Copy effects always copy only the printed values of the card, with the sole exception of other copy effects. So if you copy enchantment a Licid, you get the Licid as a creature to begin with.

5139: Dominating Licid.author: syrazemyla
5139: Dominating Licid.text_parsed:
@XTwistedsoulX: Sudden Death and Sudden Shock will work, but Krosan Grip won't. Ending the licid's effect is a special action that doesn't use the stack, like morph.

115.2c Some effects allow a player to take an action at a later time, usually to end a continuous effect or to stop a delayed triggered ability from triggering. Doing so is a special action. A player can take such an action any time he or she has priority, but only if the ability or effect allows it.

So you can pop a licid off any time you have priority, even when a spell with split second is on the stack.

The actual answer to licids is Mortify. It's not a modal spell, so it'll kill it even if it changes between casting and resolution.
5139: Dominating Licid.text_posted:
@XTwistedsoulX: [autocard]Sudden Death[/autocard] and [autocard]Sudden Shock[/autocard] will work, but [autocard]Krosan Grip[/autocard] won't.  Ending the licid's effect is a special action that doesn't use the stack, like morph.

A player can take such an action any time he or she has priority, but only if the ability or effect allows it.

So you can pop a licid off any time you have priority, even when a spell with split second is on the stack.

The actual answer to licids is [autocard]Mortify[/autocard].  It's not a modal spell, so it'll kill it even if it changes between casting and resolution.

Experiment Kraj places a +1/+1 counter on this and uses the ability. Amusingly the oracle text wording changes how this works: On the card it's part of the ability, whereas on Oracle the "control" part is a static ability on the Licid and therefore not copied by Kraj.

...wait. What happens if Kraj then uses a fight ability, like the one on Durkwood Tracker for instance? Probably the same thing as someone trying to deal combat damage to a Lumithread Field, but still.

5139: Dominating Licid.author: Aquillion
5139: Dominating Licid.text_parsed:
This card lost a huge amount of power when that M10 rules change removed damage from the stack. Back when damage used the stack, you could steal an opponent's creature, use it to chump-block or suicide attack, then pull the Licid off it while it has lethal damage on the stack and it'd die, leaving you with a Licid you could use to steal something else.

No longer works. And unlike most such tricks, you can't do it at all anymore, because pulling the Licid off before combat damage is done results in the creature being removed from combat and surviving. Oh well.

5139: Dominating Licid.author: Norin-the-Wary
5139: Dominating Licid.text_parsed:
So, I was making an Experiment Kraj EDH deck, and I went to look through gatherer of all the nice activated abilities that he could borrow. This card popped up, and I decided to give it a shot. This licid is INCREDIBLE. It dodges so many attempts to remove it, and most of the other attempts that would kill it (such as Maelstrom Pulse were countered. 5/5 without a doubt.

5146: Ertai, Wizard Adept.author: drpvfx
5146: Ertai, Wizard Adept.text_parsed:
Compare to Time Elemental in both cost and ability.

It would be *awesome* to have both of them out with Training Grounds in EDH.
Use TE to bounce something hated back into their hand,
then use Ertai to counter it.

Then again, an Isochron Scepter could also cast either Boomerang or Counterspell for 2,
without any combos needed (other than the Imprint), and a total CMC of UU less.

I guess it never hurts to have a back-up plan.

5157: Forbid.author: stygimoloch
5157: Forbid.text_parsed:
Don't let the apparent card disadvantage fool you - this is very, very powerful. But incredibly obnoxious. I've seen people voluntarily forfeit matches a good few times just because they were just getting frustrated and bored by the opponent Forbidding everything they tried to do.

On the whole, I'm fairly glad that this level of uninteractive countermagic is no longer a part of the game. It's dull, it slows down games and there's often no skill to playing it, just a Pavlovian mentality of "Counter that. Counter that. Counter that." "But it was just a 1/1!" "I don't care, I'm still countering it."

Which isn't to say Forbid is a bad card, it CAN be used well, but I wasn't sorry when it left the majority of formats.

5157: Forbid.author: Salient
5157: Forbid.text_parsed:
Forbid is hilarious in a Madness deck. You can potentially discard-cheat a Big Game Hunter or a Basking Rootwalla into play, or even plop down a surprise Brain Gorgers. Another fun card to pair with this is Circular Logic, though it's sort of redundant.

I tried building a deck with four Forbid, four Foil, and four Life from the Loam to recover discarded lands. It wasn't tournament quality, but it was fun to play. I think it might work better with Crucible of Worlds replacing Loam.

5157: Forbid.author: Enelysios
5157: Forbid.text_parsed:
One of the best counterspells in the game, but for a different reason from most of the other champs. Force of WIll, Mental Misstep and Daze can be played with no mana; keeping you safe in legacy. Spell Pierce and Spell Snare are cheap and effective. Mana Drain and Cryptic Command are played for additional effects, giving you advantage over your opponent.

Only Counterbalance and Forbid are played for their ability to be reused. This is terrible; nothing is worse than having everything countered by your opponent. It is bad for the game of magic. It makes the game less interactive.

That said, this card is very very good. I am sorry to everyone I have played it on.

5157: Forbid.author: Lazrbeams
5157: Forbid.text_parsed:
It's really only good in Casual and EDH, in other 60-card formats, the card disadvantage is too much to buy back most of the time, leaving you with a cancel. In any of the 60 card formats it's in, having a Cancel in hand is a bad place to be.

That being said, works great with card-advantage generals, like zedruu, the greathearted, damia, sage of stone, Edric, spymaster of Trest, and azami, lady of scrolls. Forms a soft lock that's very tough to escape.

5159: Fugue.author: DrJack
5159: Fugue.text_parsed:
OK, I removed my original comment because I've been informed that the term "fugue" isn't just a musical one - it can also refer to a rare psychological disorder where a person suffers episodes of temporary amnesia. Guess I should'a known, right? My sincere apologies, I assumed we were talking about the much more well known meaning of "fugue", which is a musical piece involving 3 or more melodies in counterpoint, usually performed on organ or harpsichord, associated with the Baroque period of musical history.

Now Kirbster, don't arrogantly tell me to "go to school" like a snotty 12-year old. I've studied fugues! I've played them too. Have you? All the fugues I've ever seen were instrumental and involved at least 3 interacting melodies. Many fugues are written for organ, which allows for playing 4 voices simultaneously with help of the footpedals. And yes, I've done that too. You're misconception of a fugue being "2 or more people singing" sounds like you've got fugues confused with canons (or some other thing), such as what one would find during the Renaissance.

Anyway, I'll let my original closing sentence remain:
...
Boys, it's time for you to get acquainted with J.S. Bach's "Well Tempered Klavier" books and listen to some performances of the prelude & fugues contained within. They're transcendant, after all.

Despite Dr. Jack's insistence, going so far as to post an identical comment on both versions of a card, the term "Fugue" does not refer exclusively to a type of musical piece. This actually fits the form and function of the card quite well.

...also considering a musical Fugue involves two or more people singing, I really don't think some goof sitting at an organ portrays this very well either. Go back to school, Doc.

It seems a little weird, but I'm pretty sure this is how the ability works.
5176: Null Brooch.text_posted: I'm pretty sure a hand of 0 cards still counts as a hand, or else your hand would cease to exist when you have no cards in it. 5176: Null Brooch.author: Falgorn
5176: Null Brooch.text_parsed:
If your hand is empty, it still counts as a hand and can be discarded to pay for the cost. Therefore, you can use this ability freely if you have no cards in hand. Now, if Null Brooch stated that you have to discard a certain number of cards, it would be a different story (for example, this is the case with Avatar of Discord)

Also, if an empty hand did not count as "hand", a player with no cards in hand would be an illegal target for Mind Rot.

5176: Null Brooch.author: doolydooly
5176: Null Brooch.text_parsed:
Discarding a hand of 0 is perfectly valid and probably the best use of this card, the fact that this is causing so much confusion boggles my mind.

Spells/abilities that involve your hand don't just fizzle if you have 0 cards, they interact with your hand and thus the 0 cards that are there.

Have to discard a card? Discard nothing.
Have to reveal your hand? Reveal nothing.
Have to discard your hand? Discard nothing.
Something checking hand size? It's a hand size of 0.

If a hand size of 0 ceased to be a hand then the whole Hellbent mechanic wouldn't work at all.

It's really as simple as that.

5176: Null Brooch.author: DarthParallax
5176: Null Brooch.text_parsed: "Counter target spell" is clearly one of the best things that a card can say. Be straightup honest- I mean that it ranks up there with 'win the game' (#1), 'take an extra turn' (#2), and is maybe in the Top 5 lines of text it's possible for a card to have. Look at what we pay for such effects. Pact of Negation, Force of Will. I understand that a lot of people want Counterspell back. But I don't think it's happening in Standard or Modern. There are cards that look like some of the worst wastes of cardboard/pieces of trash ever in a 'generic'/'Limited'/Casual build, but in a correctly specialized Constructed deck, it seems that almost no price is to high too pay to "Counter target spell", and this means that a card as quick and easy at doing it as Counterspell is...unlikely to pass Development anymore.

Great card, probably one of the better uses of Buyback. Usually when you have to start using artifact destruction you wind up having to use it repeatedly. Depending on the deck you're up against the 5cmc-per-turn cost for getting rid of an artifact might be worth it.

I still have some Shatters, but the only reason I ever put them in a deck is for nostalgia's sake. In all other cases it's Shattering Pulse for my red artifact destruction needs.

6031: Soltari Visionary.author: Internet_decks_lame
6031: Soltari Visionary.text_parsed:
Arguably better then Trygon Predator. Although Trygon can pick between artifact or enchantment and its toughness is 3, but it forces you to run G/U which are not the best colors for a quicker offensive strategy. Visionary being all white can easily fit into any weenie white and makes an incredible 3 drop having shadow. And shadow is clearly superior to flying. Its pratically unblockable. Usually enchantments play a larger part then artifacts in slowing down weenie speed.
Example: Propaganda, Engineered Plague, Ghostly Prison and many other disruptive enchantments that really bog down weenie decks.
Well here is the perfect solution, a white phantom warrior that munches on enchantments.

5/5

Soltari troopers and Champions are better for an agro deck, and if you are mono white, the priest and the monk are better still.
However, in slow multiplayer, this can be a great way to lose friends.
Shadow was annoying during tempest block because is skewed all decks and forced everyone to have a response to these unblockable creatures.
Now a days it is downright evil to pull them out, especially with a repeatable destruction ability.

6036: Allay.author: endersblade
6036: Allay.text_parsed:
I actually kinda like this. Too bad it can't destroy artifacts- that's what kills it.

That's what Shattering Pulse is for. They basically made a buyback card for each color that does something it's good at;
Green Constant Mists (Fog)
Blue Capsize (Boomerang)
White Allay (Disenchant)
Black Disturbed Burial (Raise Dead)
Red Shattering Pulse (Shatter)

I run this card in every EDH deck that has white in it. Having a reusable Disenchant is invaluable in that format.

6041: Keeper of the Light.author: Mode
6041: Keeper of the Light.text_parsed:
Synergizes with Sanguine Bond...NOT

But although it's arguably the worst of the five keepers, I think it's underrated.

The possibility to gain 3 life each turn for one mana - as long as you have less than your opponent - ain't that bad.

It might find some use in a weird deck that uses cards which profit from lifegain like Ajani's Pridemate, Cradle of Vitality or Well of Lost Dreams. Especially the last one can provide crazy card advantage.

Use cards that let you sacrifice life Wall of Blood (and fetchlands), or cards that give your opponent life like Wall of Shards to ensure your opponent has more life than you.
Try to build some sort of survival control deck that eventually finishes with some alternate win-con which doesn't care about your opponent's life total.

With all that walls you could possibly build some whacky defender deck with Perimeter Captain, Overgrown Battlement and maybe Stalwart Shield-Bearers.
Doran, the Siege Tower coincidentally just seems to come in the right colors for that.

6041: Keeper of the Light.author: DarthParallax
6041: Keeper of the Light.text_parsed:
if it gained you 5 life....that might have been tolerable....but it also would have made it playable.

the thing is, Lifegain is a defense ability. When it's playable, Control is playable.

When Control is what's best, Magic moves so far towards skill-testing that it -does- become less accessible to new players.

it's better for them to shift back and forth between Control being good and not good. When Control is Bad, New Players can pick up the game. When Control is Good, established players can enjoy the game. :)


when Midrange is all you got, that's like picking between Justin Beiber and Miley Cyrus XP

6046: Reconnaissance.author: Ideatog
6046: Reconnaissance.text_parsed:
And don't forget that First Strike and Double Strike create an extra combat step and therefore an extra round of priority to exploit. Combo this with Knighthood and run your creatures off after they've dealt their damage!

(Edit), @ Teufelhunden0311:

Qtd. in magic comprehensive rules,

702.7b If at least one attacking or blocking creature has first strike or double strike (see rule 702.4) as the combat damage step begins, the only creatures that assign combat damage in that step are those with first strike or double strike. After that step, instead of proceeding to the end of combat step, the phase gets a second combat damage step. The only creatures that assign combat damage in that step are the remaining attackers and blockers that had neither first strike nor double strike as the first combat damage step began, as well as the remaining attackers and blockers that currently have double strike. After that step, the phase proceeds to the end of combat step.

So, you can activate the reconnaissance ability after the combat damage is already dealt in the first step but before the second step. The ability doesn't prevent damage that has already been dealt, it just removes the creature from combat (after which it can't deal damage, hence the reminder text).

6046: Reconnaissance.author: Artscrafter
6046: Reconnaissance.text_parsed:
5/5 for versatility and low cost. They would never print a one-drop enchantment that says "creatures you control have vigilance" these days, even without all the other cool stuff you can do with this.

Pretty much every aggro deck ever will love this card since it basically lets you turn your entire board sideways every turn regardless of the enemy's board position.

For those of you who haven't figured it out yet, here's how you use this card. Oh, and the fact that combat damage doesn't use the stack anymore makes pretty much not a lick of difference.

- Your creature is blocked unfavorably? Untap it to save it from being killed during the declare blockers step.
- Your creature has first strike and you still want it to deal its damage without taking any in return? Untap it during the round of priority between combat damage steps.
- Done dealing your damage with an unblocked or chump blocked creature? Untap it after damage has been dealt during the combat damage or end combat steps. (Players get priority during both of these.)

Note that the "doesn't deal or receive combat damage" reminder text is just that, reminder text. It assumes you're untapping the creature before the combat damage step. It doesn't go back and retroactively prevent damage that has already been dealt if you activate this after combat damage happens.
6046: Reconnaissance.text_posted:
5/5 for versatility and low cost. They would never print a one-drop enchantment that says "creatures you control have vigilance" these days, even without all the other cool stuff you can do with this.

Pretty much every aggro deck ever will love this card since it basically lets you turn your entire board sideways every turn regardless of the enemy's board position.

For those of you who haven't figured it out yet, here's how you use this card. Oh, and the fact that combat damage doesn't use the stack anymore makes pretty much not a lick of difference.

- Your creature is blocked unfavorably? Untap it to save it from being killed during the declare blockers step.
- Your creature has first strike and you still want it to deal its damage without taking any in return? Untap it during the round of priority between combat damage steps.
- Done dealing your damage with an unblocked or chump blocked creature? Untap it after damage has been dealt during the combat damage or end combat steps. (Players get priority during both of these.)

Note that the "doesn't deal or receive combat damage" reminder text is just that, reminder text. It assumes you're untapping the creature before the combat damage step. It doesn't go back and retroactively prevent damage that has already been dealt if you activate this after combat damage happens.

6046: Reconnaissance.author: Aquillion
6046: Reconnaissance.text_parsed:
Note that this card gives all your creatures vigilance, since they're still "attacking creatures" during the end of combat step and can be untapped then, after they've dealt damage -- they still do their damage and you get to untap them. See the relevant rule:

511.3. As soon as the end of combat step ends, all creatures and planeswalkers are removed from combat. After the end of combat step ends, the combat phase is over and the postcombat main phase begins (see rule 505).

You can activate instant-speed effects during the end of combat step, and as that rule indicates, attacking creatures only get removed from combat at the end of that step; so during that step, you can use this card on a creature that has already dealt its damage to untap it, for free.

In other words, all your creatures effectively have vigilance (as long as they don't have shroud or protection from white or something else that would keep you from using this to untap them.)
6046: Reconnaissance.text_posted:

You can activate instant-speed effects during the end of combat step, and as that rule indicates, attacking creatures only get removed from combat at the [i]end[/i] of that step; so during that step, you can use this card on a creature that has already dealt its damage to untap it, for free.

In other words, all your creatures effectively have vigilance (as long as they don't have shroud or protection from white or something else that would keep you from using this to untap them.)

6046: Reconnaissance.author: Yukikah
6046: Reconnaissance.text_parsed:
Honestly I love the errata: It really felt like a loophole that you could use the ability after damage (normal damage, not first strike) had been dealt, or at the least that it certainly didn't feel like the spirit of what Recon was trying to do. It still largely negates any of your opponent's combat schenanigans (giant growth, Heroic triggers, etc) and lets you attack with impunity if you have more creatures than your opponent. And, frankly, the most interesting interactions with this card aren't effected anyways.

1) Red/White swarm, attack with Raid Bombardment out then just untap anything that's blocked.

2) Green/White, attack each turn with any creature with a Lure effect and just remove the creature from combat each turn for reusable unblockable attacks.

3) Attack with impunity with your Battlecry creatures to pump your worthwhile attackers; even if they can block your Accorder Paladin with a 1/1 or such, you can just untap and save them.

4) Attack with even 0 power creatures to trigger Beastmaster Ascension to quickly pump your creatures.

The possibilities are endless really with attack triggers and many other things.

6048: Oath of Lieges.author: ninjabear
6048: Oath of Lieges.text_parsed:
So, if I have 3 lands (one of them a fetch) and my opponent has 3 lands, is there a way to order the stack as to be able to find a card?

From what I see, this is "at the beginning of your upkeep", so you can't do anything before this. Furthermore, the target requirement is checked when this is put on the stack "target opponent who controls more lands than you", so I understand the ability will simply fizzle and never be put on the stack, without you having any chance of activating the fetch to do your shenanigans. Even if it was put in the stack and checked on resolution, the fetch activation would be on top so when this would resolve, you would still have 3 lands (the fetch would have resolved). Am I saying it wrong?
6048: Oath of Lieges.text_posted:
So, if I have 3 lands (one of them a fetch) and my opponent has 3 lands, is there a way to order the stack as to be able to find a card?

From what I see, this is "at the beginning of your upkeep", so you can't do anything before this. Furthermore, the target requirement is checked when this is put on the stack "target opponent who controls more lands than you", so I understand the ability will simply fizzle and never be put on the stack, without you having any chance of activating the fetch to do your shenanigans. Even if it was put in the stack and checked on resolution, the fetch activation would be on top so when this would resolve, you would still have 3 lands (the fetch would have resolved). Am I saying it wrong?

6048: Oath of Lieges.author: Etsap
6048: Oath of Lieges.text_parsed:
@ninjabear: This is covered in the rules, and the short answer is indeed that there is no way to stack your fetch land usage in that scenario. You have to have fewer lands when your upkeep starts (before activating or triggering any other abilities) in order for this to work.

603.4. A triggered ability may read "When/Whenever/At , if , ." When the trigger event occurs, the ability checks whether the stated condition is true. The ability triggers only if it is; otherwise it does nothing. If the ability triggers, it checks the stated condition again as it resolves. If the condition isn't true at that time, the ability is removed from the stack and does nothing. Note that this mirrors the check for legal targets. This rule is referred to as the "intervening 'if' clause" rule."
6048: Oath of Lieges.text_posted:
@ninjabear: This is covered in the rules, and the short answer is indeed that there is no way to stack your fetch land usage in that scenario.  You have to have fewer lands when your upkeep starts (before activating or triggering any other abilities) in order for this to work.

603.4. A triggered ability may read "When/Whenever/At [trigger event], if [condition], [effect]." When the trigger event occurs, the ability checks whether the stated condition is true. The ability triggers only if it is; otherwise it does nothing. If the ability triggers, it checks the stated condition again as it resolves. If the condition isn't true at that time, the ability is removed from the stack and does nothing. Note that this mirrors the check for legal targets. This rule is referred to as the "intervening 'if' clause" rule."

6049: Limited Resources.author: DarthParallax
6049: Limited Resources.text_parsed:
Has exactly the same problem as Balance, including the reasoning behind it's supposed 'fairness'-- being a White card and affecting everyone.

I think that should point to exactly how to judge it:

In 1v1 EDH, where both players are trying to Combo.
In Vintage and some Legacy, where both players are trying to Combo, Lock, or Race with supreme *ruthlessness* (the creature deck there is called "Hatebears")
And in any highly competitive 2 or 3 player games, where the decks are pretty much
trying to win, or gain dominance, relatively fast, and the game is some-number-of-ways Mexican Standoff.

In those games, it's pretty fair, because after all "every card has an answer", and in fact this is easily a legitimate justifiable response to someone splurging on a Fastbond/Primeval Titan gravy train.

For any 3 or more player game where some players want to run Tribal (even the powerful Merfolk, Goblin, and Elf tribes with their Aether Vial), some players want to run simplistic Creatures & Removal, some players want to run Duel Deck-power level "Themes", and all the players want to have a reasonable number of turns with back and forth and Board Wipe of CREATURES and ARTIFACTS aplenty (because people actually get the chance to play a lot of creatures and artifacts), then this card is extremely oppressive in any games with more than 2 players. (I didn't name Enchantments or Planewalkers in the Wipes, because most Enchantment strategies are going to combo off, or be solved with Targeting someone's VOLTRON and because Planeswalker Wiping is just plain a Rare Occurrence, although a FUN one to see :)

Standard this is ban-worthy, Modern this may or may not be ban-worthy, but it would certainly be Format Warping, and would probably require them to make some cards Modern-Legal that they wouldn't want to make Modern-Legal.

This isn't explicitly Johnny. This isn't even explicitly LD. Balance or Sphere of Resistance are the two cards to point to. This is specifically PRISON Control-Combo. Comtrol. Its for raising the competitiveness of any game. It's when you want to shoot to kill. Its as Spike as it gets.

6050: Cataclysm.author: swagtusk
6050: Cataclysm.text_parsed:
Okay to everyone who says the art and flavor text don't make sense, it depicts the finality of the battle of the skyship Weatherlite and the Predator flagship.
The Weatherlite was victorious over the Predator in a battle over Urborg.
It ties into the meaning of Cataclysm which is:
a large-scale and violent event in the natural world.
It is all part of the magic the gathering story and lore.
These cards are more than just pictures and effects.

6053: Exalted Dragon.author: DarthParallax
6053: Exalted Dragon.text_parsed:
You guys don't get it, do you?

Angels might, sometimes, when they're ordered to by God anyway, care about humans. Maybe.
Dragons? Demons? Behemoths? Hydras? Since when was it THEIR job to ensure YOUR victory?

oh, I see-- you're a planeswalker. You're special.

Dragons don't care two cents about that. Summoning giant creatures is impressive because most of them don't like being summoned!

Welcome to Advanced Dungeons and Dragons: 101! (This isn't the Girl Scouts- you should leave your deckboxes at home and try grabbing some REAL weapons. Preferably ones not made of cardboard.)
Forget everything else you ever thought you knew about dragons, and repeat after me:
"I am a weak, tasty human."
"Dragons eat nerds like me. All the time."
"I should be THANKING Wizards that this is ONLY a Dungeons and Dragons creature, NOT a Dungeons and Dragons land" (like Tomb of Horrors. *shudder*)

It could have been worse, people. It could have been much, much worse.
Tomb of Horrors: Legendary Awful Place To Be
Tomb of Horrors enters the battlefield tapped and does not untap at the beginning of your upkeep.
When Tomb of Horrors enters the battlefield, put a 10/10 Indestructible Hexproof demilich token with flying, haste and double strike into play. Target opponent gains control of it, then chooses all permanents you control, and destroys them. Then exile target hand attached to your arm and all cards it is holding, all the clothing you're wearing, and shuffle your graveyard into your library. Do Not pass Go, Do Not collect 200 dollars. You cannot lose the game due to having 0 life. You cannot gain life. You cannot draw cards. You cannot lose due to poison. You cannot win the game.
T: You lose the game. (If you ever find out how to tap this, you WILL, just to make it stop. Assume your opponent has cheated this under your control using Mindslaver and shenanikers.)

6053: Exalted Dragon.author: Radagast
6053: Exalted Dragon.text_parsed: I stumbled across this card while searching for 6 cost Dragons that would work well in a Commander deck. This horrible card wouldn't work in any deck! It seems like some ghastly tribute to Elder Land Wurm, an equally useless 5/5 white "dragon" that couldn't attack until some absurd condition was met. Elder Land Wurm, while horrible, at least had the excuse that it was printed when Magic was very young and was in a set surrounded by other terrible creatures. There's no excuse for this pile of drek. Even by this point, a 5/5 flyer for 4WW would have been considered "decent" - slapping a killer drawback on it makes it useless. Had it been a 6/6, it still would have been useless, but at least it could be sort of justified. Worst. Dragon. Ever.

6056: Merfolk Looter.author: tenkaze
6056: Merfolk Looter.text_parsed:
I'm glad I'm not the only one who feels Ron Spencer's art is more at home on the side of a van than in Magic.

To all the downvoters, let me clarify: His use of highly contrasting colors is a pain to look at and makes everything look unnatural, and he doesn't seem to know what eyelids are. All the people in his art have big ol' bug eyes, making them all look eternally bewildered or psychotic. He can't even draw a cuddly bear without making it look threatening. He's good at drawing ugly things exploding, but it'd be nice if his skills were a bit broader.

Bring back Rebecca Guay!

6061: Fade Away.author: KillerWhiskey
6061: Fade Away.text_parsed:
Luckily, it's compatible with several other cards blue has to offer, like Propaganda. At some point, your opponent will have to choose whether he wants to have enough mana to attack, hence sacrificing most of his creatures and preserving the lands, or sacrificing his lands to preserve the creatures as he attempts to get rid of Propaganda with enchantment removal. Either way, you achieve card advantage, but keep in mind this also affects creatures that you control. Therefore, you must either have creatures (or other permanents like Hatching Plans) with positive move-to-graveyard effect or run few to no creatures at all.

3.5/5, as it can backfire or fizzle at times.

6061: Fade Away.author: scumbling1
6061: Fade Away.text_parsed:
Not very good.

If you are casting this card, your opponent has established a threatening board presence you need to answer. If they're already in that position, that means they're probably at the top of their mana curve and they've accomplished what their deck is designed to do: rush out an army that other players can't handle. So even if you hit him with Fade Away when he is completely tapped out, the opponent can simply sacrifice his lands instead of his creatures, and keep right on winning. He doesn't need his lands anymore -- he has already paid for his victory. You're playing this card presumably to deal with creatures, but it won't reliably handle them.

6061: Fade Away.author: blurrymadness
6061: Fade Away.text_parsed:
Beautiful card for control. You already have them paying mana or tapped out for other reasons. Add this guy and all the sudden you have opponents losing their ability to function or their ability to attack *at all*.

Propaganda, Pendrell MIsts, et all are great ways to ensure you're destroying several creatures, or keeping them from attacking. Add Rystic Study and you're guaranteeing card draw. Add Sphere of Resistance and similar and enemies are stuck in a slow grind against whatever your win cons are.
6061: Fade Away.text_posted:

6072: Oath of Scholars.author: sarroth
6072: Oath of Scholars.text_parsed: Why the discard part? I expected it to read "If that player controls fewer cards in hand than target opponent, that player may draw a card." Unless your hand sucks, you're not going to want to do this if you have more than 3 cards in hand. And even so, if that opponent has more than 4 cards in their hand, drawing 3 cards didn't exactly bridge the gap between you. Not in the same way that Oath of Lieges does with land, Oath of Mages does with life totals, Oath of Druids does with creatures, and Oath of Ghouls creatures in graveyards.

6076: Mind Over Matter.author: Designer_Genes
6076: Mind Over Matter.text_parsed: The best combo enabler (in terms of balance, flavor, fun, and power) ever made.
6076: Mind Over Matter.text_posted: The best combo enabler (in terms of balance, flavor, fun, and power) ever made.

6076: Mind Over Matter.author: Sumai4444
6076: Mind Over Matter.text_parsed: Mind Over MatterMost players seem to agree, it is the most versatile combo enabler in all of MTG currently. So many cards rely on tapping, or untapping, and many powerful cards make untapping impossible, or difficult, to balance said power. But what about overcoming the cost of tapping or untapping? When I find a wonderful card like this, I see how it detracts from my deck, and I compensate for it. In this card's case, I must discard a card. First I want to find a way where discarding is not an issue, second, I want to find a way to replenish my cards to continue discarding, and finally, find a way to exploit this to my advantage over my current opponent. Making card discard not an issue is easy enough, good old Library of Leng takes care of that. Now for the fun part, figuring out a way to get steady card draw, as well as exploiting the ability to untap all day long! The quickest way for card draw is one card, or a card like it, Arcanis the Omnipotent . Let's draw three cards, then discard one to untap, and repeat the process as much as we like, oh let's hope we have Library of Leng out! Nice, infinite card draw, but why stop there? Let's do the card draw AND do some damage to our opponent! Thieving Magpie works nicely with aHermetic Study slapped on, or aProdigal Sorcerer ,or any of that cards clones with similar ability, with a Curiosity slapped on. Now we are tapping to do a point of direct damage, discarding a card to the top of our library with Library of Leng out, to untap with Mind Over Matter , right after resolving drawing a card, do do it all over again, as much as we like. Infinite Damage Combo!!! Okay so many different ways to break that multi-card combo up. But we are playing blue people, and should have some form of countering available! As for permanents, MOM should have no problem tapping whatever is causing you distress:) Time to execute is a factor though. And though this is the beginning of a very powerful combo, so many other decks will break it up in 10 or fewer turns. One option is building a smaller 60 card deck. Four Urza's Bauble , four Mishra's Bauble and four Foresight and any similar cards to slim the deck fast. But I prefer the more devious way, and would splash some green. Why stop at infinite card draw and damage? Let's go Infinite Life Combo!!! With good old Aluren , you just need an Essence Warden out, or a Paradise Plume out(choose blue!). You then proceed to playMan-o'-war . Then you play the other one in your hand for free , targeting the first. Repeat as much as you like for as much life as you like:) You may use any number of green spells to populate your hand with Man-o'-war. You also use any number of green spells for mana sources or land fetching . Any number of blue for card draw, and since you are using these colors, don't forget some Coiling Oracle and maybe a Recycle for more infinite card draw!!!

6076: Mind Over Matter.author: dberry02
6076: Mind Over Matter.text_parsed:
This is going in my Experiment Kraj EDH deck built around drawing.
Azami, Lady of Scrolls, Arcanis the Omnipotent, and Archivist will all let me draw/filter through my deck.
Combined with Earthcraft, I can untap a creature to untap a land for a bunch of mana.
If you had an Everflowing Chalice in play, this could get really nasty.

And for a new combo: You can combine this with Elixir of Immortality and Sorcerer's Strongbox. All you have to do is activate the ability. While it's ability is on the stack, just untap it with Mind Over Matter and do it again. As long as you don't let them resolve, you'll get their bonuses because they both don't require you to sacrifice them to activate. So for the Elixir, you can gain 5 life each time; And for the Stongbox, you get that many flips!

Have fun :)

6079: Carnophage.author: MechaKraken
6079: Carnophage.text_parsed:
This is a pretty cool card. The fact that you are losing life due to this creature will make the opponent possibly think twice about removing it. That can work in your favor, if you manage to deal 2 damage with it while only paying 1 life per turn. A 2/2 creature for only is also pretty good.

A similar scenario exists with Cloistered Youth and Herald of Torment. They can be pretty strong during the early game, but late game they start to become a hindrance since the opponent may just immobilize them with something like Pacifism or Guard Duty and let you keep taking life loss during your upkeep. Fortunately, this card in particular lets you choose whether to tap it to avoid the life loss, so that actually makes it better then Cloistered Youth in some ways.

Pretty nice design and very much in flavor with black. Try to hurt them more then you hurt yourself.
6079: Carnophage.text_posted:
This is a pretty cool card. The fact that you are losing life due to this creature will make the opponent possibly think twice about removing it. That can work in your favor, if you manage to deal 2 damage with it while only paying 1 life per turn. A 2/2 creature for only [B] is also pretty good.

A similar scenario exists with [autocard]Cloistered Youth[/autocard] and [autocard]Herald of Torment[/autocard]. They can be pretty strong during the early game, but late game they start to become a hindrance since the opponent may just immobilize them with something like [autocard]Pacifism[/autocard] or [autocard]Guard Duty[/autocard] and let you keep taking life loss during your upkeep.  Fortunately, this card in particular lets you choose whether to tap it to avoid the life loss, so that actually makes it better then Cloistered Youth in some ways.

Pretty nice design and very much in flavor with black. Try to hurt them more then you hurt yourself.

6085: Culling the Weak.author: SubstantiaNigra
6085: Culling the Weak.text_parsed:
I find this card as useful as Dark Ritual, especially in my Spirit Reanimator deck. I use it on creatures like Nether Shadow, Nether Traitor and Bloodghast to free up mana for my instants and sorceries, or for other, bigger creatures. But its uses go beyond that, easily making Culling the Weak 1 of the 3 most important cards in this deck.

Example -

Turn 1: Swamp, Dark Ritual, Entomb Iname, Death Aspect, Exhume Iname.
Turn 2: Swamp, Culling the Weak, sacrifice Iname, raise 4 Nether Traitor in addition to the 4 Nether Shadow I raised at upkeep and the 4 Bloodghast I raised when I played the second Swamp.

I then have that extra from the second Swamp to Unearth any of the more use-specific Spirit creatures, such as Kataki, War's Wage (if I'm playing against Affinity/Artifacts) or Kira, Great Glass-Spinner (if I'm playing against Control/Removal). I can otherwise save those I got from Culling the Weak to end the game early with Mortal Combat, or similarly win by using those 4x and the extra I got from the second Swamp I played to raise all my Spirits with Patriarch's Bidding.

Culling the Weak is useful in many other situations. Say my opponent drops a fattie that could really hurt me as soon as it hits the table and I only have 1 Swamp untapped but no Dark Ritual -Culling the Weak and Rend Flesh. It also helps me cast that Angel of Flight Alabaster with just and the I get from my Cavern of Souls. That's for a 4/4 with Flying that returns 1 Spirit card to me every upkeep (and that includes Nameless Inversion). I can then use Nameless Inversion as removal for small creatures or on my Thief of Hope for a small combo engine.

The sac outlet and 4x Culling the Weak also helps me cast my Karador, Ghost Chieftain early and when I don't have enough creatures to reduce his cost to .

6085: Culling the Weak.author: tavaritz
6085: Culling the Weak.text_parsed:
What were the rules when this was printed?

Under Revised rules any cost that was presented cost: effect format without tapping as cost could be paid several times as a bundle. So you only needed to activate your COP: Black once when you paid five black mana to Pestilence.

So under those rules you could sacrifice several creatures when playing this and get the effect as many times as the number of sacrificed creatures.
6085: Culling the Weak.text_posted:
What were the rules when this was printed?

Under Revised rules any cost that was presented cost: effect format without tapping as cost could be paid several times as a bundle. So you only needed to activate your COP: Black once when you paid five black mana to [autocard]Pestilence[/autocard].

So under those rules you could sacrifice several creatures when playing this and get the effect as many times as the number of sacrificed creatures.

6091: Dauthi Cutthroat.author: blurrymadness
6091: Dauthi Cutthroat.text_parsed:
Kind of a pain to get going due to needing other cards to work to full effectiveness and such, but easy to use creature kill that pumps Dauthi Ghoul at the same time is a big deal over the course of a game. The biggest issue is simply the lack of available shadow creatures to truly build powerful decks from. Dauthi Warlord and Ghoul are easy to use for heavy aggro and the control theme opens itself much more to being controlled.

I'd recommend instead using Dauthi Trapper and standard kill cards to pump the Ghoul while not worrying about removal, summoning sickness, etc.. Anytime something is going to die, tap the trapper so Ghoul gets his free pump. No mana, easy to do.

This guy has a place, but again, the control theme works less well with a standard shadow deck built around the dauthi, and works much better instead as a comborific repeatable destroy. That said, usually Royal assassin will treat you better as he's only one card, helps keep opponents at bay (for the threat of destruction) and BEGS to be removed. This guy tells you that you can remove something else to render him harmless, which is largely what makes him less attractive.
6091: Dauthi Cutthroat.text_posted:
Kind of a pain to get going due to needing other cards to work to full effectiveness and such, but easy to use creature kill that pumps [autocard]Dauthi Ghoul[/autocard] at the same time is a big deal over the course of a game. The biggest issue is simply the lack of available shadow creatures to truly build powerful decks from. [autocard]Dauthi Warlord[/autocard] and Ghoul are easy to use for heavy aggro and the control theme opens itself much more to being controlled. 

I'd recommend instead using [autocard]Dauthi Trapper[/autocard] and standard kill cards to pump the Ghoul while not worrying about removal, summoning sickness, etc.. Anytime something is going to die, tap the trapper so Ghoul gets his free pump. No mana, easy to do. 

This guy has a place, but again, the control theme works less well with a standard shadow deck built around the dauthi, and works much better instead as a comborific repeatable destroy. That said, usually [autocard]Royal assassin[/autocard] will treat you better as he's only one card, helps keep opponents at bay (for the threat of destruction) and BEGS to be removed. This guy tells you that you can remove something else to render him harmless, which is largely what makes him less attractive.

6094: Dauthi Warlord.text_parsed:
Ridiculously low cost for what can potentially become a very, very powerful card. Hell, even with nothing else on the table it comes out as a 1/1 with an evasion ability for 2cmc, which is decent. It only gets better from there as the game goes on; how many other cards can you say that about?

I'd say it should have first strike, but with Shadow that's kind of moot since your opponent is not likely to be running Shadow creatures.

Very, very powerful card in the right deck. It's only powerful and not completely overpowered because there's not much out there in the way of creating token creatures that have Shadow.

This would be awesome to revive in a Leyline adaptation, maybe requiring you to exile the cards from your hand instead of discarding them -- you could cause both players to begin the game with no cards in hand (I guess the opponent would have one card in their hand). It would be interesting, at least.

As it is, I wish Dungeon was cost-efficient enough to at least playtest in Dredge decks; it would be the best discard outlet available if the didn't nix it.

BloodDragon -- you can only play the discard ability as a sorcery, so it's essentially impossible to activate in response to the 5-life-destruction ability (maybe there's some crazy way to put together some weird trickery that lets you play whatever sorceries you like at flash/instant speed during an opponent's turn, but not even Teferi can pull that one off).

6100: Volrath's Dungeon.author: SeriouslyFacetious
6100: Volrath's Dungeon.text_parsed:
This card is another in the long line of Black "suicide" enchantments going all the way back to Lich and Greed. Yes I realize this particular card has no life/draw interaction, but it's still related.

They hit a couple bullseyes with Necropotence and Yawgmoth's Bargain... but where can you really go from there?

This is one of the failures, see also Colfenor's Plans. Many a player has tried real hard to make these work...

This is only really good in multiplayer like EDH where you can get 30 cards in hand and treat it like a sorcery. Then dump everything you don't need to force all other players place their entire hands on to their libraries.

6103: Recurring Nightmare.author: JaxsonBateman
6103: Recurring Nightmare.text_parsed:
Edit: after having made another deck with this card in it (to try and take advantage of the casual-sexiness that is Ulvenwald Tracker), it just boggles the mind how broken this card is in casual circles, with the main culprit this time around being Acidic Slime. Acidic Slime on the field and in the grave = repeatable Stone Rain. Stone Rain should not be so easy to achieve. Throw in Ulvenwald Tracker and you have another source of repeatable removal. Love the card so I'll keep playing it, but it does make me feel a little dirty knowing how difficult it can prove to be at times.



@WhiteMcFly: no, you can't bring back the creature you just sacrificed. While players often shortcut their way around casting spells and activating abilities, doing the steps in any order to reach the final goal, technically costs are always paid AFTER targets are selected. That is, the creature won't be in the graveyard by the time you're choosing a target.

Personally, I didn't know this card existed until I did a random search on Gatherer. Glad I found it. Can't wait to combo it up with some token generation and some ETB/LTB madness. Would also go quite well with Grave Pact to pile up the pain - oh, not only do I get my best creature back, but you also have to sac one. Sorry!

@Cheza - you'll notice my explanation specifically said targetting was the problem. ^^ It's not a tricky difference at all with Master Transmuter either; Master Transmuter doesn't target (and spells and abilities never target cards within hidden zones), so it doesn't target.

Just made another deck with this, and it's just absurd how good it is. I was concerned with my first test game being against treefolk (and my only way of dealing with indestructibility being a single Duplicant), but fortunately, a single Shriekmaw + Solemn Simulacrum meant I kept hitting their creatures down so that they could never get 2 Timber Protectors out, and the Simulacrum meant I was generating a wad of card advantage at the same time.

6104: Hatred.author: MagicJohn
6104: Hatred.text_parsed:
A very good card. Many times read: pay almost your life: win the game.

As it can be countered after you paying the life it can be very disappointing when your opponent have a Force of Will or Cancel.

We know new players don't like having their spells countered. It is more disapointing when that spell takes the additional costs away!

If they change the additional costs rule to be payed always during resolution, the game would be funnier.

'qq wahhhhh overcosted. blah blah blah'
Not in an environment where Dark Ritual and Culling the Weak are present.


'but then if your opponent Stp, bolt, or bounces....'
Most Hatred Decks run a set of Unmask and/or Duress so with even minimal effort you can KNOW weather or not you opponent has such effects at the ready, and in most cases, you can nullify them.

And last but not least, this card DOES age well. with the new 1cmc zombies (Diregraf Ghoul, and Gravecrawler)go well in this deck type, and the addition of Pact of Negation is a THIRD answer to 'combo breaker' cards like FoW.

6106: Raging Goblin.author: Hawk_man
6106: Raging Goblin.text_parsed: I used to play this guy in every red deck I built. He was my workhouse one drop creature and he served me well. Nowadays...maybe I've been spoiled by my playset of Mogg Fanatic and the retarded power of Tattermunge Maniac, but he seems really bad. Actually, I know he's really bad. Raging Goblin is, at his very best, going to get in there for 3 damage and then chump something. Not bad, but any red deck can do better. If you are playing a goblin deck and absolutely can't find anything else, play Raging Goblin for old times sake...but he usually underperforms.

6112: Sonic Burst.author: leomistico
6112: Sonic Burst.text_parsed:
Once upon a time, I used to play this card, and enjoyed it very much even without madness or cemetery tricks... 4 damages for only is quite powerful, considering that Lightning Bolt wasn't the standard anymore at its time, and that you have to spend something between to to achieve this amount of damages or such cards require you other form of card disadvantage! I'm thinking about Cackling Flames, Char, Flame Javelin, Lightning Blast and the like. Forgive me if I forget something...
Shrapnel Blast is a little on the broken side, in that it's an instant and there were Artifact land that helped it very much...
Artillerize... I don't know...

However, a good card whatever you haters think about it! Plus, you can copy it with, saying Izzet Guildmage and do 8 damages for , or 12 for to different targets...! For nostalgia and for its true power, I think that I'll give it a 5/5

As a side note, there aren't many damage spell with a sound-based flavour. They are all about fire, lightning or ice...

In the right burn deck, an opponent should almost never have more life than you...if they do you're probably doing it wrong or have a very bad hand..

That said, it could maybe find a home in a {R}{B} deck, since black typically has cards that create an advantage in exchange for life, such as Dark Confidant or Sign in Blood which would help trigger the opponent having more life than you clause...helping you drag them down with you.

6118: Mogg Assassin.author: sarroth
6118: Mogg Assassin.text_parsed:
@supershawn: It has more than one target. Read the Oracle Text: You choose a target and your opponent chooses a target, for 2 total targets. The ruling also says "pick the target creatures."

No one has mentioned that there is the possibility that, in a multiplayer game, your opponent might choose a creature you don't control. I'd expect that they would target one of your creatures out of spite, since you targeted one of their creatures, and I would really expect that they would target Mogg Assassin to not have to deal with it again, but if they really hate another opponent's creature and you're really good at politics, you might get in a win-win scenario. Or, if all of your creatures had shroud or protection from red, then your opponent would have to target something other than your creatures; at worst, they would target the same creature you did, and you would have a guaranteed destroyed creature.

Even without all of that, I still love this card. Sometimes you just need random effects to calm down the power level of a deck.

6118: Mogg Assassin.author: Aquillion
6118: Mogg Assassin.text_parsed:
This card is better than it looks at first, mostly because of how it works with other Goblin deck cards.

First, it can be searched up by Goblin Matron and Goblin Recruiter. This is important, because it means you can just put one in your deck, then grab it when you absolutely need some creature destruction -- with lots of searchers, goblin decks benefit from having cards that cover specific situations.

Second, you can use Goblin Chirurgeon to break symmetry, so you can sacrifice your least important goblin if you lose the toss, while destroying your opponent's most important creature if you win.

(Also fun if you have some way to give all your creatures Shroud, since that forces your opponent to target their own creatures even if you lose the flip. But Goblin Chirurgeon is the best way to use this card, since it's a cheap and easy thing to throw into any goblin deck.)

6121: Spellshock.author: raptorman333
6121: Spellshock.text_parsed:
idk why this card has such a low rating, especially with the sets that followed after exodus.
this card has "COMBO ME" written all over it:
put this in a white/red deck with Purity and you'll gain 2 life everytime you play a spell and you're opponents will get effed.
or futhermore, combo it with Overblaze and watch the damage flow--people will think twice about playing spells.
Even if you're sick of it being in out in play, disenchant it your next turn. For three mana you'll have dealt yourself 2 damage in the begining 4 turns and, in a multiplayer game, you'll have dished out more damage than you've recoiled--sort-of like a high priced Sizzle in a shallow combo.

6123: Price of Progress.author: DrJack
6123: Price of Progress.text_parsed:
There is some seriously flawed thinking going on around here.

"Damn. You guys must be rich - or have rich parents, maybe."
"5/5 stars. Thats what you get for spending more money on your lands then I did on my car.... "

I don't know why this is very difficult for some of you to understand, but..:

ALPHA DUAL LANDS AREN'T THE ONLY NON-BASIC LANDS IN EXISTENCE.

Why do you guys think everyone who runs Urza lands, pain lands, legendary lands, etc. etc. etc. deserves to suffer? For that matter, why should even people who use Alpha dual lands be punished so severely? What was their crime? Wanting to have fun and not be mana screwed 80% of the time?

For the record, I'm not a rich boy either. I never owned more than a couple Alpha (actually, Unlimited/Revised) dual lands. I used... (gasp in horror now) proxies. So did most of my friends. Guess what? We had a darn good time, whether we were using mono-color decks with basic lands or lands full of duals. Blood Moon, Price of Progress, and the like, were completely unnecessary. But certain individuals just can't ever leave "good enough" alone.

6134: Rabid Wolverines.author: Zoah
6134: Rabid Wolverines.text_parsed:
Oh, come on, why dose this thing have a ** */2 rating? It's at least a ***!

It costs 5 but has a 4/4, true. However this creature is meant to attack with and when used as it is meant to be, it is almost granted to be a 5/5.

As far as I can see, these creatures (Wolverines, ferrets, etc) all seem to get tougher when they attack. That and it can't be blocked by more than one creature without making it even more dangerous. A whole army of ten thousand elves couldn't bring this sucker down.

At any rate, I can see this thing in two ways. First, I can see this sucker standing well alone, and second, I can see it going well in a deck structured around it and others like it.

So:

offish manna cost: -*
Ability to stand alone: +*
Ability to work with other things: +*

final rating: ****

Oh, look my rating pumped it up to ***, fantastic.

6134: Rabid Wolverines.author: jsttu
6134: Rabid Wolverines.text_parsed:
Heh, gotta love the flavortext. About the card itself a 4/4 for five isn't bad, although the double green hurts it a bit. What this card likes is to be equiped with rancor or some other means to trample over the opponents creatures, or maybe a lure or something that triggers upon damaging a player. That way a 1/1 blocker will be useless, and anything greater will still die while allowing damage to get through. Only if the blocker was a 5/5 or 2 3/3's would the opponent not take any damage, and that isn't including any possible pumps. either way you come out ahead, trading a 4/4 for a 5/5 or a 4/4 for their multiple blockers, netting either mana or card advantage. Either way, this card is something that has a niche, and shouldn't necessarily be overlooked.

That said, power creep has probably obsoleted this guy ten times over, but it was still very decent during that time period and would probably work well in casual.

6138: Jackalope Herd.author: Tensuillio
6138: Jackalope Herd.text_parsed: I used this card to devastating effect in dozens if not hundreds of pauper and/or casual duels when it came out. Why do I love it so much? Because it's nigh-unkillable. If it gets hit with removal, just cast whatever utility spell you have handy and snatch it back to your hand. Alternatively, use its "drawback" in conjunction with post-attack spellcasting to give it a sort of ghetto vigilance. This beast is criminally underrated. My playgroup learned the hard way to diregard it at their own peril.

Choose target opponent who controlled more creatures than you did as you activated this ability. Put a 2/2 green Beast creature token onto the battlefield.

I think they were trying a little too hard on this one to avoid the phrase, "activate this ability only...." I understand that you can't activate the ability unless you can target such an opponent, but it seems weird to "choose target opponent" (because you can't use target as a verb in Magic jargon) and then do nothing to the chosen opponent.
6142: Keeper of the Beasts.text_posted:
[i]Choose target opponent who controlled more creatures than you did as you activated this ability. Put a 2/2 green Beast creature token onto the battlefield.[/i]

I think they were trying a little too hard on this one to avoid the phrase, "activate this ability only...."  I understand that you can't activate the ability unless you can target such an opponent, but it seems weird to "choose target opponent" (because you can't use [i]target[/i] as a verb in [b]Magic[/b] jargon) and then do nothing to the chosen opponent.

6143: Spike Rogue.author: ScissorsLizard
6143: Spike Rogue.text_parsed:
I suspect he's not creature type Rogue because he's not a "rogue" in the sense that he is sneaky or evasive, like other rogues (like Inkfathom Infiltrator or Looter Il-Kor.)

This guy is a rogue in a different sense: he's a rogue against his own species. Unlike other spikes, he can actually steal counters away from his own kind. So he's a rogue in the same sense as Rogue Elephant, which also didn't get the creature type.

6145: Crashing Boars.author: orisiti
6145: Crashing Boars.text_parsed:
@izzet

It is slightly different, hence (part of) the reason they didn't change it.

In this case, the player may choose an untapped creature, and tap it before the Declare Blockers step to not have to block. Likewise they could choose something like Tormented soul. If it was "Crashing Boars must be blocked by at least one creature if able" The player would have to choose some creature they control that is able to block it. Honestly your version would be better (opponents having the option is always a powerbreaker, even if it is this circumstantial.)

6150: Survival of the Fittest.author: channelblaze
6150: Survival of the Fittest.text_parsed:
I agree with ace. Don't get me wrong, this card is seriously over-the-top good...but it still shouldn't be banned. Now, I'm not gonna quit playing magic because of it...but still...

I think Wizards needs to learn this: Don't ban cards because they're good. Ban cards because they ruin the game. Kinda like mystical. Sure, it was really good, but it's not like people stopped playing legacy while it existed. It's not even like legacy was less fun while it existed. Sure, survival is dominating the metagame, but so what? It makes no more sense than banning BBE "because it's really good". Yeah, it is really good. So?

6150: Survival of the Fittest.author: Smedley
6150: Survival of the Fittest.text_parsed:
The banning of this card is a ridiculous move on Wizards' part:

1). It's an enchantment, any serious player will have an answer for enchantments (and most likely artifacts) in their sideboard if not their main deck because of all the other enchantments we all know, love and fear (Counterbalance, anybody?).

2). It's an activated ability, so there are ways to prevent it or limit it (Pithing Needle, Aven Mindcensor, Suppression Field, Mindlock Orb...).

3). It fuels the graveyard, and decks that make the most aggressive use of Survival rely on their graveyards. And just like the first example, any legacy player worth their salt will have graveyard hate on hand to shut that down...I won't bother with examples because there are so many. Sure the Survuval player can still get any creature they want as long as they have something to pitch and one green to pitch it with, but that's much more manageable than Vengevines and Iona popping back into play from the 'yard.

4). It's a 2 casitng cost card, which is right in the primary range to be shut down by Counterbalance, Spell Snare, Chalice of the Void, snagged by Engineered Explosives, Pernicious Deed, and other board permanent removal.

Yes it is a very powerful card, one that can be used in many ways and is extremely versatile...but there are plenty of cards in the format that are just as ubiquitous and cause much more far-reaching changes in what is viable in the format. Survival should be allowed in the format because there are so many ways to deal with it, and all with stuff people already have access to and use frequently (and are CHEAP!!!)

6150: Survival of the Fittest.author: blurrymadness
6150: Survival of the Fittest.text_parsed:
Survival decks created Aggro/Control/Combo decks; literally good at all three. This card is one of the few that's broken Legacy in spite of free counterspells, in spite of mega-fast combo decks; nothing could match it's consistency, power, and speed at the same time.

You were going to combo? Mental Misstep or Force took care of it. They could counter your counters. They could tutor up solutions to their problems. They could combo into vengevines easily (requiring any two castable creatures, which they could tutor with this single card over the course of 4-5 mana allowing 2-3 hasty vengevines on top of their other critters)

Can't be stopped by counterspells and stifle is only card parity.

Amazing card. I hope it's never unbanned.

6150: Survival of the Fittest.author: strider24seven
6150: Survival of the Fittest.text_parsed:
@TheWrathofShane
"Cards like this are what make magic Pay 2 Win and One Sided."

I have several issues with your complaint, so I will break them down for you:
1) "Pay 2 Win"

First, Vintage Dredge would like to have a word with you. Aside from the 4x Bazaar of Baghdad, many Dredge lists cost under $50. Since unsanctioned tournaments, i.e. the majority of Vintage tournaments, usually allow 10-15 proxies, you could feasibly show up to a tournament with a deck worth less money than its sleeves.

Second, let us deal with the idiom "Pay to Win" itself. Magic: The Gathering is a Trading Card Game (TCG), so it requires some amount of monetary investment to even play the game, which, in most contexts, is required to win in the first place. This is a property of all commercially produced games, though TCG's often require sustained investment, rather than a lump sum up front like a non-subs_cription video game or a board game. Hence, the phrase "Pay to Win," is only vacuously true unless you are advocating playing with borrowed, stolen, or counterfeit cards. That being said, if you are dissatisfied with the product, that is your opinion and completely valid, but you (again, hopefully) knew that TCG's have an entrance fee: the cards themselves. Complaining that a TCG is "Pay to Win" is like buying a car and then complaining that you had to pay for the car - it serves no other purpose than to make yourself sound like an inarticulate fool.

2) "One Sided"

Now let us examine the current Legacy and Vintage metagames as of the date of this post:
Top 5 Vintage decks by volume: MUD - 20%, Fish - 15%, Snapcaster Control - 13%, Planeswalker Control - 9%, Oath of Druids - 9%, Other - 34%

No deck takes up more than one-fifth of the metagame, with the top five dominant decks taking up only two-thirds of the metagame.

Top 5 Legacy decks by volume: BUG - 15%, Stoneblade - 9%, UR Delver - 9%, Show and Tell 9%, UW Miracles 7%, Other - 51%

Legacy is even more diverse, with the dominant deck occupying even less of the metagame, and consisting of two different decks - BUG Aggro and BUG midrange. The top five dominant decks make up less than half of the metagame.

Surival was indeed a dominant deck in Legacy prior to its banning, but its matchups were by no means one-sided. At least, not until the printing of Vengevine - at which point they were not one-sided... that would be CawBlade in Standard.

Hence, Magic: The Gathering is neither "Pay to Win" nor "One Sided" - in fact, its accessibility and diversity are what make it appealing even two decades after its conception. Stop complaining about one card in a deck that beat yours and learn how to play against it, or around it, or with it - whatever suits your fancy. But leave the hate-ratings at home.

(Source for metagame stats - mtgtop8's reports on the last 12 months for Vintage, last 2 months for Legacy).

TL;DR
5/5 for a powerful and interesting card.
0.5/5 for TheWrathofShane's ignorant and needlessly querulous hate-rate post.

6151: Oath of Druids.author: Arglypuff
6151: Oath of Druids.text_parsed:
10/1/2009 The ability can only target an opponent of the current player.
10/1/2009 The targeted player controlling more creatures than the current player is a part of the targeting requirement. A player can't be targeted by this ability unless it's true, and the ability will be countered on resolution if it's no longer true at that time.

Yup. Ivory Mask will fizzle this just as it does Gifts Ungiven. If Ivory Mask is under your control ("your" being the controller of Oath of Druids also controls Ivory Mask), then your opponent cannot use Oath of Druids (except in multiplayer if at least 1 opponent is targetable).

6151: Oath of Druids.author: rmwpro
6151: Oath of Druids.text_parsed: So let's say I have the Orchard and Oath is out. I've given my opponent a creature. At the end of his turn he kills the creature and now has none. After untap can I tap the orchard to give him another? I know the Oracle says "at the beginning of my upkeep" but isn't the manna tapping effect of Orchard that produces the side effect of giving my opponent a creature fast enough to make it still work and trigger Oath?
6151: Oath of Druids.text_posted: So let's say I have the Orchard and Oath is out. I've given my opponent a creature. At the end of his turn he kills the creature and now has none. After untap can I tap the orchard to give him another? I know the Oracle says "at the beginning of my upkeep" but isn't the manna tapping effect of Orchard that produces the side effect of giving my opponent a creature fast enough to make it still work and trigger Oath?

6151: Oath of Druids.author: apollogod
6151: Oath of Druids.text_parsed:
@rmwpro

No player has priority between untap and the upkeep steps. Any triggers that occur "at the begining of your upkeep" will be placed on the stack before you have priority to tap any lands for mana.

The trigger for oath is checked twice: Once upon being triggered, and again upon resolution. If the opponent does not control more creatures that you at either time, the ability will not resolve.

So, no. You will not get priority to tap the orchard before the trigger would be placed on the stack (hence, Oath would not trigger at all).

@rmwpro

Oath of Druids' ability will trigger at the begining of your upkeep. Sorry, but @apollogod is right. Oath of Druids' ability has a target. If your opponent doesn't have a creature at the beginning of your upkeep, then you can't target them and so the ability never goes on the stack in the first place. Giving them a creature during your upkeep is too late.

Deserves 4.5 to 5 points. Whenever it hits play, people groan, because the Weaver simply dominates the whole combat. Even if you have no way to add counters, it's a highly versatile card, generating up to 3 fogs at will, or moving counters around. 4.5/5

6155: Mirri, Cat Warrior.author: blurrymadness
6155: Mirri, Cat Warrior.text_parsed:
Formidable, especially when backed by burn or -x/-x effects. Why? Because you can fool an opponent blocking with a 4/4 into walking into a Disfigure; turning a dead kill card into a live one.

First strike is one of my favorite abilities because of that. You don't need pump spells, you just need good old-fashioned burns or shrinks; which are good in the first place.

Forests are popular right now too, making it a good attacker and defender in the meta-game. 1-of it with Green sun's zenith and you should be good to go!

6156: Workhorse.author: Magnor_Criol
6156: Workhorse.text_parsed:
I agree with the general consensus that mana of any color would've been far better. But there's some potential (janky) usefulness; since there's no activation restriction, it can be popped all at once for a four-mana burst.

If you power him out early - say, T3 Palladium Myr, T4 this guy - You can then have a one-time burst of 11 mana on turn 5. (Assuming you've dropped a land each turn.)

That's far from exceptional, but it's certainly an interesting way to get a lot of mana in a sudden. T5 Ulamog, the Infinite Gyre or Darksteel Colossus isn't too bad either, especially considering you get style points for doing it so strangely.

...So, it really just depends, but the Library is probably better.

6158: Spellbook.author: scumbling1

6163: Erratic Portal.author: ForestFire0
6163: Erratic Portal.text_parsed:
@MojoVince: I think you may be misunderstanding the rules of the verb "exchange". An exchange can only take place if both permanents are on the battlefield at the time the ability would resolve. So if you are suggesting to play the drake, bounce it in response to it's trigger, then get your opponent's creature without giving him anything, that won't work. If you're saying bounce the drake once your opponent gets it, that would work but would require your opponent to not have any mana available.

@John-Bender: Equilibrium's ability costs plus the cost of the creature and can only be used (most of the time) when you can cast a sorcery. Erratic Portal can be used any time, can save your own guys, and forces your opponent to keep mana up. Equilibrium is good, but so is this card.
6163: Erratic Portal.text_posted:
@MojoVince: I think you may be misunderstanding the rules of the verb "exchange". An exchange can only take place if both permanents are on the battlefield at the time the ability would resolve. So if you are suggesting to play the drake, bounce it in response to it's trigger, then get your opponent's creature without giving him anything, that won't work. If you're saying bounce the drake once your opponent gets it, that would work but would require your opponent to not have any mana available.

@John-Bender: Equilibrium's ability costs [1] plus the cost of the creature and can only be used (most of the time) when you can cast a sorcery. Erratic Portal can be used any time, can save your own guys, and forces your opponent to keep mana up. Equilibrium is good, but so is this card.

6167: Memory Crystal.author: The_Murderauder
6167: Memory Crystal.text_parsed:
Perhaps this isn't the best page to be having this conversation, but I just can't resist.

Why are you people obsessed with devour? Why do you feel the need to consolidate your billions of points of power into a single creature? You're actually making a worse play by doing so. Easier to block, easier to kill, steal, lock, etc. Sure, devour 2+ nets you a larger total P/T, but that doesn't even matter when you're dealing with infinite combos.

I'm just saying, there's more targeted removal in the game than there is mass removal. And much more instant-speed targeted removal. The only one of these suggestions that had any amount of merit was Predator Dragon, and only because it has haste. And frankly, there are better options in that department too.


As for Memory Crystal, I like it! It's interesting to me that they even printed this at all. There are only 30 cards in the entire game that it even interacts with (not counting Blast From the Past). But it's great at what it does.

6168: City of Traitors.author: fissionessence
6168: City of Traitors.text_parsed:
Andrew's Occasional Random Card of the Day #12 - 7/8/2011 - City of Traitors

This card really promotes early explosive plays. That's the type of game play that Wizards doesn't really print cards for anymore. Plan on winning on turn two or three using the extra mana generated from City of Traitors? Well, enjoy it in your legacy format, because you probably won't be seeing new cards like that. Even newer cards like Mox Opal that push the modern boundaries of fast mana encourage you to play more permanents, forcing you to spend more cards on your board position, rather than rewarding you for playing fewer lands and more expensive and powerful spells.

I think this card reads like a Spike card to most informed people today, but a less informed (on average) Magic population of the past might have seen this more as a Johnny card. And in a way it is. It has a pretty severe drawback, but with big potential. Figure out how to mitigate that drawback and reap the rewards. It turns out that the way to mitigate the drawback is to be a Spike and use the mana to just kill your opponent before you need another land. Or play Crucible of Worlds. Or both.

6168: City of Traitors.author: chrisAAMO
6168: City of Traitors.text_parsed:
@ Sironos, regarding flavor:
It's old, but if you've heard anything about Volrath's Stronghold on Rath, this is the city that was built below it to house his minions. These minions were traitors of their own people and moved here. If I remember, the city's population all fled when Volrath's Stronghold was invaded by the good guys (Eladamri, Lord of Leaves and his elf army).

It's supposed to represent Volrath The Fallen's minions abandoning the city. I guess to be more accurate, the card could have read "At the end of each turn, if you were attacked this turn, sacrifice City of Traitors."

If you compare the artwork from Volrath's Stronghold to this card, you can see how they fit together.

6168: City of Traitors.author: DrJack
6168: City of Traitors.text_parsed:
In regards to the flavor text: well, that's what you get for allying with people that call themselves "il".

Some people think this card's broken. I don't know. I think Ancient Tomb is considerably further up the scale of brokenness. City of Traitors is closer to Crystal Vein in terms of power. Any land that provides 2 mana and doesn't come into play tapped is worth a good look, to be sure.

@ Kragash, now that you mention it, City of Traitors does indeed combo with ITSELF quite nicely. Turn 1, play City of Traitors. Turn 2, tap city for 2 mana, play another city, tap it for 2 more mana... how about a nice Juggernaut? True, you could do the same with a Dark Ritual, but with City, you don't even need to rely on having any black mana. Play this card alongside bounce effects, artifact mana, Crucible of Worlds, and also feed it to things that require land sacrifices. You will indeed see profit.
